MARTIN: Without a mask on, by the way, you don't want to be seen buying those things.

MACDONALD: I don't care, I love it. I love Twinkies, and --

MARTIN: I want a picture.

MACDONALD: You know what I'm excited about Jonathan Hoenig. We have Zingers coming back, and Ho-Hos coming back, Ding Dongs. Jonathan Hoenig, should we be saying, should the company be sending a big box of Ding Dongs to that union that helped drive -- the Hostess into bankruptcy. Go ahead, Jonathan.

HOENIG: Well, they are American classics, happy they are back, Liz. Unfortunately, it was unions not the public taste that was really keeping them down. You know, in a free market there are an unlimited amount of jobs, manufacturing Twinkies, TV sets or anything that can be created. Unfortunately, it has been difficult for manufacturing companies to actually produce because the economics have to work. So it is great to see private equity investors, and job cuts, new jobs created and the Twinkies live.

MACDONALD: I like the company that bought Twinkies. They have all major food groups they have Blue Ribbon beer. They have Bumble Bee Tuna. They've got Pam cooking spray and that Golden's mustard, what are you talking about healthy choices here?

MARTIN: Exactly. Jonathan, don't make me come over there because here's the issue. I mean, if you are asking for Twinkies to carry this company into sunset, you guys are nuts. Believe me the first day, they sell them, I think it will be great, but you know, weeks, three, four, and five forget about it.

MACDONALD: All right, you made your point. Hoenig you are up first to answer this question, if Disney executives are happy with "Monster University's" Box Office finish now. What are they going to do if viewers were able to watch it at home? This is huge a trend taking a hold overseas. Disney, Sony testing a new business model that will let movie lovers rent films at home on the very same day they are released in movie theatres. Jonathan, is this a smart strategy?

HOENIG: It is terrific. Entertainment companies, Liz are innovating. Gone are days of standing in line with that big stack of grimy VHS videotapes. I mean, the whole world of entertainment from Netflix to Red Box down the line have made getting wonderful films and entertainment, better, cheaper, more accessible and more efficient for the consumers. So I think that is would be a tremendous win not only for the studios, but ultimately for the consumer who gets higher quality entertainment at a lower price.

MACDONALD: Scott, does -- are we going to see here in the United States, we're already seeing it for independent films that you get movies on pay- per-view at same time, they are in the movie theatre, is there -- do you see any time in future, Scott Martin, where the viewer at home can watch those same movies the day they are released?

MARTIN: I hope so. I think it is a big one. My VHS tapes were never grimy, thank you very much. But, I tell you --

MACDONALD: They had Twinkies all over them and Ding Dongs.

MARTIN: You are right, but, situation at movie theatre, when you go out and fill your tank up with gas, you have to park. It's very expensive so nowadays with kids and people staying home and save money, I think it is a great idea to stream the stuff right to their homes and not have to leave the house to see it.

MACDONALD: Scott Martin, I know you like healthy living so you will love this next topic. You're going to answer the first question on this one. Is Pepsi caving to food police, focusing on being not just a soda company, but also expanding to healthier options. We're going to have Pepsi selling yogurt. So Scott, are you going to be drinking a Diet Pepsi with your yogurt?

MARTIN: That's kind of a funny issue, isn't it? Now it's kind of the anti- Twinkie. I mean, they are going the other direction, which you got to get credit for. But, do you want to eat yogurt that's made by Pepsi. They have a longstanding reputation in soda, Frito-lay chips. I don't know if yogurt's going to sell real big for them.

MACDONALD: Jonathan Hoenig, is Pepsi responding to the market?

HOENIG: They are responding to the market. This is not an appeal to the health conscious people. The fact is that Greek yogurt is like what hot wings was in 2010. It's like what the avocado was in 2006, a hot food trend. So I think Pepsi is just really capitalizing on this. They are out to make money. I don't think that America's waistline is their number one priority nor should it be.

MACDONALD: Pepsi is not responding to the food police, do you think they are?

MARTIN: No, but, you have to fit the company or say the product into the image. Listen, I'm all for them expanding their product line. Yes, the Greek yogurt area is growing considerably, but still, if you're at the store, you think of Pepsi, you are buying soda.

MACDONALD: You know, I for one, dipping my Frito-Lay chips into my yogurt with my Diet Pepsi.

MARTIN: It sounds tasty to me.

MACDONALD: I'll be having my Ding Dongs smeared over with Golden Mustard how is that?

MARTIN: You go on those diets, and we'll come back in a year.

MACDONALD: We'll say woo-hoo with a Pepsi blue ribbon beer. Good to be with you, gang, so funny and so smart.

Next up, this 4th of July, get ready for some fireworks, but not in the sky, at the super market because you know, what, your barbecue will burn a hole your wallet.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Well, the 4th of July is almost here, before you start grilling, prepared to get grilled at the supermarket because food prices are exploding like fireworks, ground beef, chicken breast, potatoes, all up significantly from last year. So you know what is up? Let's ask commodity analyst, Phil Flynn. Phil, what is going to with these food prices going up?

PHIL FLYNN, THE PRICE FUTURES GROUP: You know, I tell you, it has a lot to do with a lot of issues. I think more than anything it was last year's drought. You know cost of feed for chickens and cattle went through the roof, that is one of the reasons why the price of steak is approaching $5 a pound toward the 4th of July. That is almost un-American, you know, how could you not have a thing without steak? Then chicken going up. Only thing that is flat right now are hotdogs and I guess, hotdogs is pretty American, but you're going to have to stick to that.

MACDONALD: Let's break it down. Are you having a cheap bas barbecue with cheap food?

FLYNN: Right, you can bring back Twinkies. But, you know, the bottom line is that we had a challenging year, when it comes to cattle, next year, I think they will look better, global demand will be down, it looks like we'll have a pretty get crop. The prices should be down, one thing that government continues to want us to pay higher prices they find new ways to do it, instead of taking corn, feeding it to cattle and chicken so my chicken wings are cheaper they put it in our gas tank.

They will improve that that has been another thing, a lot of chicken producers are screaming bloody murder, saying you are driving up the cost of feed. It is harder for me to feed my chickens. So, you know, at the end of the day, it's going to cost us all more.

MACDONALD: Phil, you make such an important point because we had big agricultural company executives taking at Capitol Hill and saying, you know what? This is just foolish what you are doing with ethanol and corn in the gas tank. It is not working it is making corn more expensive, and making gas prices more expensive and ruining the gas tank.

FLYNN: It is, now with this rule by the Supreme Court, the 15 percent, you know, it could do damage to your vehicle. A lot of the carmakers are not going to say that warranty is valid because they didn't produce these vehicles and these engines for 15 percent ethanol. It will be a scary time, but government does not want to hear that. They think this is a good deal. It's good for the environment. Tell that to people around the world who are starving right now. It's not such a great idea.

MACDONALD: You know that is a concern, you know that poor people around the world, they are not getting the food supply as they could. But that point about car warranty may not cover your gas tank if basically corn ethanol wrecks it. Is that true?

FLYNN: It's true, a lot is not just automobile makers, but small engine makers, you know, lawn mowers, your snow blowers. You know, a lot of these makers are saying we didn't sign for this. We produced an engine that was supposed to be protecting 10 percent ethanol. Nobody said 15 percent and they think it could damage some of the vehicles. The people on other side say, it is not going to impact anything, but tell that, if you have a problem, your gas tank rusts out and you want to get it fixed they will tell you sorry, Charlie, you are out of luck.

MACDONALD: Why chicken? Why is it going up so much?

FLYNN: It was really the drought last year. Remember last Super Bowl, I was panicked they were talking about a chicken wing shortage that was you know, a throw away item here. And then, then we have shortage. We have a big price spike on chicken wings then the prices came back down. A lot of it has been the drought. Feed cost has gone through the roof, you look at price of corn, it has been through the roof. I do think it is going to ease a little bit, but, you know not fast enough for the 4th of July.

MACDONALD: You say food prices are going to come down, is that your final word?

FLYNN: They will come down. We have a good crop this year. China is slowing down a little bit. Pricing should come down once government figures out a new way to waste food.

MACDONALD: OK, Phil Flynn, thank you so much. Always good to be with you, sir. Thanks so much for your time.

Next up, tech companies fighting back against government snooping, but you will not believe the next story, could it be just for show, they gave a big fat award to NSA top guy. We are going to let you in on the next big secret, don't go away.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: All right, on the surface tech companies appear to be fighting back against NSA snooping, but you dig deeper, you might come up with a different opinion because a trade group representing Microsoft and Google and the like just gave NSA Head General Keith Alexander the, quote, "Government Executive Of The Year Award" for this year. A weird way to express disappointment and we're back with Peter and Ron and Imogen.

IMOGEN LLOYD WEBBER, POLITICAL COMMENTATOR: Silicon Valley are in bed with the government, the former head of Facebook security now works for NSA and you look at these lobbying numbers, Facebook money on lobbies up 196 percent last year. They want the government on the side.

MACDONALD: Here is the thing, Ron Meyer, Google and Facebook and Microsoft, saying that is terrible, we're getting pressure by U.S. to give information over, but here you have one of the biggest tech lobby groups giving an award to the NSA. Is the tech crowd, is Silicon Valley becoming more like Wall Street with the turn style between Silicon Valley and Washington, D.C.?

MEYER: Well, it makes business sense for them to do it unfortunately and that is the problem.

MACDONALD: Why all of the shock, shock? You know from "Casablanca" on part of the tech crowd when they are doing this on the side.

MEYER: You talk about two different parts of the company, one is the PR side talking with customers. The other is lobbying side talking with government. The problem is they don't want people to think that is what they are doing, but they are, from a consumer perspective this worries me, young people are furious over this that we have some companies we trust with most private information working with the government and allowing them to do the large general warrants.

MACDONALD: Peter, does this undercut tech crowd's credibility?

SUDERMAN: I think those big tech companies like Google and Facebook are really in a tough position because they have to ask themselves, is it more trouble to work with the federal government or is it more --

MACDONALD: That's not my question. Is this undercut their credibility when tech lobby is giving an award to head of NSA, and we have a turn style between Silicon Valley and WashingtonD.C., with law enforcement and surveillance crowd?

SUDERMAN: You know, certainly is does not make it easier for them, but that is my point.

MACDONALD: Does it under cut their credibility?

SUDERMAN: It does not make it easier for them to oppose the government efforts. So in some ways it had the potential to do, but this is what I'm trying to say they have a tough choice to make. So when federal government comes knocking on their door, they have to decide do we answer or not.

MACDONALD: Does it under cut their credibility when they get so upset?

WEBBER: Of course it does, on many levels we should have expected it. We knew, but problem is money and politics. American politicians spend over $7 billion last year, getting re-elected. They have to raise that money, and get it from somewhere. They get it from big business.

MACDONALD: You know, Ron, the question, I'm thinking, could the tech crowd have avoided this. Could they have -- tech crowd have gone around this, said, we're going to like we sell our information to advertisers, tech crowd makes money marketing from giving in account to marketers -- giving information to marketers, could they say we'll sell the information to the government.

MEYER: Well, I think that would be a more open process, I think it -- might make people read the terms of agreement when you join these sites, if you know your information is going to the government. I feel that users don't know that, it would be a more open process.

MACDONALD: Peter, tech crowd is feeling put in a corner. Go ahead.

SUDERMAN: I mean, with question of whether or not they could have sold it, you have to ask, whether the federal government would have been willing to pay for it the issue that tech community has learned that it is difficult to ignore requests of the federal government, if you call them requests.

MEYER: Quote, unquote.

SUDERMAN: They are demands, Microsoft tried in 90s and found out activity easier to play ball.

MACDONALD: But why could they have said you can -- you know stomp your feet all you like we'll sell it to you.

MEYER: Tell that to a court order.

SUDERMAN: Whether federal government would have paid.

MACDONALD: I hear what you are saying, Ron, about the FISA court, but, you know I understand the weight and authority of the FISA court, I get it but you know, these are not you know, the lilies of the valley, they are big companies. And they are going to buckle under a FISA court order. I understand they have to comply, but do you feel they could have put up more of a fight.

MEYER: I think it is a double standard, you add Google opposing internet regulation bill last year, they are companies of people, when it looks good for them, and good to be in with government they are, they are losing a ton of credibility.

MACDONALD: Imogen, go ahead.

WEBBER: They want government on their side for tax, and antitrust legislation, and legislation to privacy, of course, they are not going to turn to government say go away.

MACDONALD: You say, they can't, they would poison the well of goodwill.

WEBBER: I'm saying they need government on their side.

MACDONALD: All right, Peter, final word.

SUDERMAN: I guess, I feel like you know, too much to -- it may be too much to expect Facebook and Google to really put up a huge amount of resistance given their relationship with federal government, and what federal government can do to them.

MACDONALD: Thank you for watching America. I hope you have a good evening.

END

urn:contentItem:5KRW-JYR1-DY0W-43BT-00000-00Snowden Flight Examined; Hackers from India Allegedly Hitting US Targets; Immigration Reform and Business; Companies Performing Background2013-06-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:44ZLexisNexisSnowden Flight Examined; Hackers from India Allegedly Hitting US Targets; Immigration Reform and Business; Companies Performing BackgroundLanhamFULL TEXT

LIZ MACDONALD, FBN ANCHOR: The White House slamming China and Russia over their handlings of NSA leaker Ed Snowden, but instead of backing down, those countries are smacking us down.

Welcome everybody, I am Liz MacDonald in for Neil Cavuto. So good to be with you tonight. The administration is angry at China for letting Snowden leave Hong Kong for Moscow, and even angrier at Russia for refusing to release the guy to the United States and Craig Smith says the U.S. is looking weak, and in debt so he's not surprised and former CIA operative Mike Baker, also here.

Craig, let's start with you. I mean China, the idea that China can protect its civil liberties that is a laugh and a half. But you think it's because of our debt picture here at home, that's why basically we're getting thumbed - the nose is thumbed at us overseas. Go ahead.

CRAIG SMITH, SWISS AMERICA TRADING CORP. CHAIRMAN: Yeah, I think that's part of it, Liz. But I also think it's a lack of leadership in the White House. I mean if we had a strong president right now, he should be able to pick up the telephone, speak to the premier of China, speak to Vladimir Putin. I mean remember when, you know, before the election, hey, after the election I can be more flexible? I remember back, Liz, when Ronald Reagan was our president, while he was being sworn into office, 444 days of our people being held hostage, they were releasing the hostages. Why? Because they knew they had a strong man in the White House, they did not have somebody that was just playing president, he was being president and leading, and that is why I think that they are paying no attention to what Mr. Obama wants, quite frankly.

MACDONALD: You know, Mr. Baker to Craig's point here. It's about restoring U.S. economic strength. You can have these grand global ambitions with your foreign policy, right? You can do - you could talk about fixing climate change and global poverty. You know people would say some people say yeah, that's what we should do. But you can't do it if you don't have economic strength at home, right?

MIKE BAKER, FMR. CIA COVERT OPERATIONS OFFICER: Well, I think it's absolutely true, and I think you'd have to go back a number of years to find when our relations, particularly with China and Russia were this bad. And it really does speaks to the lack of leverage, to the lack of influence that we have, the lack of respect that we're getting there. But I don't think you can discount also the politics of this, as well, and what I mean by that is, I'm not going out on a limb by saying that, you know, this White House, screwed the pooch on Benghazi out of political fear over what a problem on the ground in Benghazi could mean for the looming presidential election, so it is not a big stretch to say that, you know, is this White House really excited to actually, despite what they are saying right now? To get their hands on Snowden, get him back here, and then have the spectacle of a trial. What all that would mean, keeping the story on the front pages ahead of the midterm elections, I think that can't be discounted when we are looking, because I hate to think that the White House is so incompetent right now that they were not able to pressure, to strong arm, to get China's cooperation.

MACDONALD: You know, you know, you make a great point, Mike. And Craig, here is the deal. I mean right now the Snowden case, what we know right now about it, right? Is that this was a guy complaining about U.S. surveillance of citizens. Let's be clear. We don't know if there was any leaks that he's giving to overseas countries like - counties overseas such as China. So what I'm - but the point being is that essentially this is a story line where Russia is saying the United States has been overzealous as a global cop, that we've have been overreaching, we've been overplaying our hand, but to Mr. Baker's point, that if we have an unstable United States, that means instability in the Middle East, and it gets problems like Benghazi and Libya. Go ahead.

SMITH: Absolutely right. Mike - Mike - Mike hit it all, it's all political, look at Benghazi, we're going to go out and get the bad guys, man, well, he does nothing about it. We don't even know who told the story and the fib about, you know, it was a video on YouTube. And Mike is correct, we've had a deterioration of our relationships with Russia and China, and I believe part of it is due to the economic stress that we've had between the nations, and think about it, do we really believe that Vladimir Putin does not want to have some dominant position in the world? And if we have allowed relationships to get so bad, to where our president, the leader of the free world cannot pick up a telephone, which I doubt, and again, I'm speculating on this, E-mac , but I don't think he picked up the telephone and called the premier or called Vladimir Putin, and said, hey, I need you, guys, to work with me, let's work this thing out, we need this guy back home, we've got to find out what happened.

And look, Mike and I would agree, this guy is a bad guy, he stole things from America, he is a thief at least, I mean who knows what he has given up, but again, we don't know, so why don't we work with China and Russia, to get him back and find out what happened? The answer is, they are telling us to go fly a kite, Liz .

MACDONALD: Yeah.

SMITH: And they have every right to do it, quite frankly, because of the way they've been treated.

MACDONALD: You know, Mike, I'll tell you, it's still a striking, and no small irony, Mike, that you know Snowden is running to countries that are so against civil liberties, I mean you're going to find civil liberties in China and Russia? You know, the thing is, we said, for decades the U.S. there has been complaints about the U.S. being the world's global cop, but right now it seems to me that countries are being more vocal and more forward about their criticisms publicly in the press. Go ahead.

BAKER: Right. Well, I think they can afford to do that, because again, our credibility are - and it's not even so much credibility, because, you know, it really is a lack of leadership. And it is sort of a plank (ph) position of weakness. And that, you know, Putin loves nothing more than to stick it in whenever he's got the opportunity. You know, the Chinese relationship has always been fraught with nuances and difficulties, but it really is incredibly poor at this point. You know, to your point, about what he's actually told Snowden, meaning what he's actually given up, he sat in Hong Kong and provided to the Chinese information about our national security posture towards the Chinese government. Now, you know, people have been conflating that thing, well, look, I mean, that, you know, we are beating up on the Chinese over their decades of economic espionage and stealing of our military and government secrets. And so, it is only fair play, but it's not. We're working in a different world than the Chinese are. Chinese have an economic miracle because they were willing existentially to steal everything, and so I am worried, that as with a lot of these stories, they've become so layered, that you start to lose fact - track of the matters.

MACDONALD: And you say, you start to lose .

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: Yeah, you start to lose perspective, because China certainly is not a country with a lot of economic liberties, like we have here in the United States, right? Final word, Mr. Baker. Go ahead.

BAKER: Well, again, I'm stunned, I made the mistake early on as this story was breaking to say that, you know, I thought we would get Snowden back in short order, I could not imagine that our relationship with China will be so bad that they would be willing to blow it up over letting him go, I was wrong.

MACDONALD: All right, Craig Smith.

SMITH: Send Mike in, he'll get him.

MACDONALD: OK, send Mike .

SMITH: Send Mike in - Michael will go get him, I guarantee you.

MACDONALD: All right. Thank you, guys. Good to be with you tonight. Next up China keeps getting away with hacking us, so no wonder its neighboring India is getting in on the act, and cyber criminals in that country accused of hitting the United States targets including the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and Heritage's Dean Cheng on how China's bad habits are spreading. Dean, take it.

DEAN CHENG, HERITAGE FOUNDATION ASIA EXPERT: Well, what we're seeing right now, is to build off your previous guests, the fact that we have a weak economy. We have a president who is unable to make commitments that he can live up to. And most recently, he almost desperately invited the Chinese premier out to Rancho Mirage, and the Chinese slapped him in the face but not even willing to spend the night at the resort. They stayed at a separate hotel, to send the message, we don't trust you, and we don't think you're going to do anything if we insult you.

MACDONALD: All right, but if you take a step back, I hear what you're saying, take a step back. Is it getting easier for any big player to get in on the act of cyber hacking or has this been a story that's always been out there that has not been reported on? Go ahead.

CHENG: It is - look. Somebody who is smart with a laptop can operate from an Internet cafe anywhere in the world, they are smart they can create botnets and they can start doing all sorts of nastiness, the problem with Mr. Snowden is, he knows all the counter measures. He knows all the things that we do to try and keep other people from being able to use that.

MACDONALD: All right, but stay on India, who is cyber hacking in India? And what are they going after?

CHENG: I think that in the case of India, you've probably got actors who are interested in commercial opportunities, contracts, who is going to make a play for an acquisition or who would - the Indians like to partner up with. Basically, you can see the people hold cards.

MACDONALD: All right, is there cyber hacking coming out of Pakistan?

CHENG: At this point there is probably cyber hacking coming out of every country, but I think that India simply for its sheer size, but also it's much more advanced IT capacity, is probably a little bit more of concern than Pakistan.

MACDONALD: Dean, are you concerned that rather than these countries building a functioning economy that they are turning instead to cyber hacking?

CHENG: I think for particularly countries whose economies are already rickety, places like Pakistan, places like Venezuela, they are going to look at this, as the way out. And it's not. I mean the thing is that at the end of the day if you really want to build an economy, you have to have a fully functional system, but for some of these countries, what they are really after is political. They want political control, and cyber is a way to do that. So, it's both econ and politics.

MACDONALD: OK. Final point. Dean, quickly, three sec - we only have a limited amount of time. Which countries are you most worried about in terms of cyber hacking the United States and their companies here?

CHENG: Well, I think China and Russia absolutely lead the pack. Believe it or not, North Korea is another source, and we are probably going to start seeing more things coming from South America.

MACDONALD: So, the final question: North Korea is cyber hacking the United States., what are they cyber hacking here?

CHENG: They are trying to break into our military, but they are also trying to break into things like our power grids and any other parts of the communications and information backbone, ways to hurt the United States, cheaply but devastatingly.

MACDONALD: OK. Dean Cheng, thank you so much for being with us tonight, it's really good to see you, sir. Next up, coming up how the government could force businesses to hire ex-cons. This sounds criminal, but it's true. Next, also thousands of pages, hundreds of surprises, and costing billions of dollars. No, I'm not talking about the health care law. You know all about that one. We're talking about the immigration bill that is giving businesses a lot of headaches.

IMOGEN LLOYD WEBBER, POLITICAL COMMENTATOR: Silicon Valley are in bed with the government, the former head of Facebook security now works for NSA and you look at these lobbying numbers, Facebook money on lobbies up 196 percent last year. They want the government on the side.

MACDONALD: Here is the thing, Ron Meyer, Google and Facebook and Microsoft, saying that is terrible, we're getting pressure by U.S. to give information over, but here you have one of the biggest tech lobby groups giving an award to the NSA. Is the tech crowd, is Silicon Valley becoming more like Wall Street with the turn style between Silicon Valley and Washington, D.C.?

MEYER: Well, it makes business sense for them to do it unfortunately and that is the problem.

MACDONALD: Why all of the shock, shock? You know from "Casablanca" on part of the tech crowd when they are doing this on the side.

MEYER: You talk about two different parts of the company, one is the PR side talking with customers. The other is lobbying side talking with government. The problem is they don't want people to think that is what they are doing, but they are, from a consumer perspective this worries me, young people are furious over this that we have some companies we trust with most private information working with the government and allowing them to do the large general warrants.

MACDONALD: Peter, does this undercut tech crowd's credibility?

SUDERMAN: I think those big tech companies like Google and Facebook are really in a tough position because they have to ask themselves, is it more trouble to work with the federal government or is it more --

MACDONALD: That's not my question. Is this undercut their credibility when tech lobby is giving an award to head of NSA, and we have a turn style between Silicon Valley and WashingtonD.C., with law enforcement and surveillance crowd?

SUDERMAN: You know, certainly is does not make it easier for them, but that is my point.

MACDONALD: Does it under cut their credibility?

SUDERMAN: It does not make it easier for them to oppose the government efforts. So in some ways it had the potential to do, but this is what I'm trying to say they have a tough choice to make. So when federal government comes knocking on their door, they have to decide do we answer or not.

MACDONALD: Does it under cut their credibility when they get so upset?

WEBBER: Of course it does, on many levels we should have expected it. We knew, but problem is money and politics. American politicians spend over $7 billion last year, getting re-elected. They have to raise that money, and get it from somewhere. They get it from big business.

MACDONALD: You know, Ron, the question, I'm thinking, could the tech crowd have avoided this. Could they have -- tech crowd have gone around this, said, we're going to like we sell our information to advertisers, tech crowd makes money marketing from giving in account to marketers -- giving information to marketers, could they say we'll sell the information to the government.

MEYER: Well, I think that would be a more open process, I think it -- might make people read the terms of agreement when you join these sites, if you know your information is going to the government. I feel that users don't know that, it would be a more open process.

MACDONALD: Peter, tech crowd is feeling put in a corner. Go ahead.

SUDERMAN: I mean, with question of whether or not they could have sold it, you have to ask, whether the federal government would have been willing to pay for it the issue that tech community has learned that it is difficult to ignore requests of the federal government, if you call them requests.

MEYER: Quote, unquote.

SUDERMAN: They are demands, Microsoft tried in 90s and found out activity easier to play ball.

MACDONALD: But why could they have said you can -- you know stomp your feet all you like we'll sell it to you.

MEYER: Tell that to a court order.

SUDERMAN: Whether federal government would have paid.

MACDONALD: I hear what you are saying, Ron, about the FISA court, but, you know I understand the weight and authority of the FISA court, I get it but you know, these are not you know, the lilies of the valley, they are big companies. And they are going to buckle under a FISA court order. I understand they have to comply, but do you feel they could have put up more of a fight.

MEYER: I think it is a double standard, you add Google opposing internet regulation bill last year, they are companies of people, when it looks good for them, and good to be in with government they are, they are losing a ton of credibility.

MACDONALD: Imogen, go ahead.

WEBBER: They want government on their side for tax, and antitrust legislation, and legislation to privacy, of course, they are not going to turn to government say go away.

MACDONALD: You say, they can't, they would poison the well of goodwill.

WEBBER: I'm saying they need government on their side.

MACDONALD: All right, Peter, final word.

SUDERMAN: I guess, I feel like you know, too much to -- it may be too much to expect Facebook and Google to really put up a huge amount of resistance given their relationship with federal government, and what federal government can do to them.

MACDONALD: Thank you for watching America. I hope you have a good evening.

END
