urn:contentItem:58RJ-T5M1-JB20-G4W0-00000-00Snowden Flight Examined; Hackers from India Allegedly Hitting US Targets; Immigration Reform and Business; Companies Performing Background Checks on Employees Discriminating Against Minorities?; Twinkie Homecoming; Tech Companies and the Government2013-06-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:44ZLexisNexisCAVUTO8:00 PM ESTCraig Smith, Mike Baker, Jennifer Bonjean, Nicole Deborde, Imogen Lloyd Webber, Ron Meyer, Peter Suderman, Dean Cheng, Ben Willis, Jonathan Murray, Scott Martin, Jonathan Hoenig, Phil FlynnNEWSFinancial062401cb.223Snowden Flight Examined; Hackers from India Allegedly Hitting US Targets; Immigration Reform and Business; Companies Performing Background Checks on Employees Discriminating Against Minorities?; Twinkie Homecoming; Tech Companies and the GovernmentElizabeth MacDonald

LIZ MACDONALD, FBN ANCHOR: The White House slamming China and Russia over their handlings of NSA leaker Ed Snowden, but instead of backing down, those countries are smacking us down.

Welcome everybody, I am Liz MacDonald in for Neil Cavuto. So good to be with you tonight. The administration is angry at China for letting Snowden leave Hong Kong for Moscow, and even angrier at Russia for refusing to release the guy to the United States and Craig Smith says the U.S. is looking weak, and in debt so he's not surprised and former CIA operative Mike Baker, also here.

Craig, let's start with you. I mean China, the idea that China can protect its civil liberties that is a laugh and a half. But you think it's because of our debt picture here at home, that's why basically we're getting thumbed - the nose is thumbed at us overseas. Go ahead.

CRAIG SMITH, SWISS AMERICA TRADING CORP. CHAIRMAN: Yeah, I think that's part of it, Liz. But I also think it's a lack of leadership in the White House. I mean if we had a strong president right now, he should be able to pick up the telephone, speak to the premier of China, speak to Vladimir Putin. I mean remember when, you know, before the election, hey, after the election I can be more flexible? I remember back, Liz, when Ronald Reagan was our president, while he was being sworn into office, 444 days of our people being held hostage, they were releasing the hostages. Why? Because they knew they had a strong man in the White House, they did not have somebody that was just playing president, he was being president and leading, and that is why I think that they are paying no attention to what Mr. Obama wants, quite frankly.

MACDONALD: You know, Mr. Baker to Craig's point here. It's about restoring U.S. economic strength. You can have these grand global ambitions with your foreign policy, right? You can do - you could talk about fixing climate change and global poverty. You know people would say some people say yeah, that's what we should do. But you can't do it if you don't have economic strength at home, right?

MIKE BAKER, FMR. CIA COVERT OPERATIONS OFFICER: Well, I think it's absolutely true, and I think you'd have to go back a number of years to find when our relations, particularly with China and Russia were this bad. And it really does speaks to the lack of leverage, to the lack of influence that we have, the lack of respect that we're getting there. But I don't think you can discount also the politics of this, as well, and what I mean by that is, I'm not going out on a limb by saying that, you know, this White House, screwed the pooch on Benghazi out of political fear over what a problem on the ground in Benghazi could mean for the looming presidential election, so it is not a big stretch to say that, you know, is this White House really excited to actually, despite what they are saying right now? To get their hands on Snowden, get him back here, and then have the spectacle of a trial. What all that would mean, keeping the story on the front pages ahead of the midterm elections, I think that can't be discounted when we are looking, because I hate to think that the White House is so incompetent right now that they were not able to pressure, to strong arm, to get China's cooperation.

MACDONALD: You know, you know, you make a great point, Mike. And Craig, here is the deal. I mean right now the Snowden case, what we know right now about it, right? Is that this was a guy complaining about U.S. surveillance of citizens. Let's be clear. We don't know if there was any leaks that he's giving to overseas countries like - counties overseas such as China. So what I'm - but the point being is that essentially this is a story line where Russia is saying the United States has been overzealous as a global cop, that we've have been overreaching, we've been overplaying our hand, but to Mr. Baker's point, that if we have an unstable United States, that means instability in the Middle East, and it gets problems like Benghazi and Libya. Go ahead.

SMITH: Absolutely right. Mike - Mike - Mike hit it all, it's all political, look at Benghazi, we're going to go out and get the bad guys, man, well, he does nothing about it. We don't even know who told the story and the fib about, you know, it was a video on YouTube. And Mike is correct, we've had a deterioration of our relationships with Russia and China, and I believe part of it is due to the economic stress that we've had between the nations, and think about it, do we really believe that Vladimir Putin does not want to have some dominant position in the world? And if we have allowed relationships to get so bad, to where our president, the leader of the free world cannot pick up a telephone, which I doubt, and again, I'm speculating on this, E-mac , but I don't think he picked up the telephone and called the premier or called Vladimir Putin, and said, hey, I need you, guys, to work with me, let's work this thing out, we need this guy back home, we've got to find out what happened.

And look, Mike and I would agree, this guy is a bad guy, he stole things from America, he is a thief at least, I mean who knows what he has given up, but again, we don't know, so why don't we work with China and Russia, to get him back and find out what happened? The answer is, they are telling us to go fly a kite, Liz .

MACDONALD: Yeah.

SMITH: And they have every right to do it, quite frankly, because of the way they've been treated.

MACDONALD: You know, Mike, I'll tell you, it's still a striking, and no small irony, Mike, that you know Snowden is running to countries that are so against civil liberties, I mean you're going to find civil liberties in China and Russia? You know, the thing is, we said, for decades the U.S. there has been complaints about the U.S. being the world's global cop, but right now it seems to me that countries are being more vocal and more forward about their criticisms publicly in the press. Go ahead.

BAKER: Right. Well, I think they can afford to do that, because again, our credibility are - and it's not even so much credibility, because, you know, it really is a lack of leadership. And it is sort of a plank (ph) position of weakness. And that, you know, Putin loves nothing more than to stick it in whenever he's got the opportunity. You know, the Chinese relationship has always been fraught with nuances and difficulties, but it really is incredibly poor at this point. You know, to your point, about what he's actually told Snowden, meaning what he's actually given up, he sat in Hong Kong and provided to the Chinese information about our national security posture towards the Chinese government. Now, you know, people have been conflating that thing, well, look, I mean, that, you know, we are beating up on the Chinese over their decades of economic espionage and stealing of our military and government secrets. And so, it is only fair play, but it's not. We're working in a different world than the Chinese are. Chinese have an economic miracle because they were willing existentially to steal everything, and so I am worried, that as with a lot of these stories, they've become so layered, that you start to lose fact - track of the matters.

MACDONALD: And you say, you start to lose .

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: Yeah, you start to lose perspective, because China certainly is not a country with a lot of economic liberties, like we have here in the United States, right? Final word, Mr. Baker. Go ahead.

BAKER: Well, again, I'm stunned, I made the mistake early on as this story was breaking to say that, you know, I thought we would get Snowden back in short order, I could not imagine that our relationship with China will be so bad that they would be willing to blow it up over letting him go, I was wrong.

MACDONALD: All right, Craig Smith.

SMITH: Send Mike in, he'll get him.

MACDONALD: OK, send Mike .

SMITH: Send Mike in - Michael will go get him, I guarantee you.

MACDONALD: All right. Thank you, guys. Good to be with you tonight. Next up China keeps getting away with hacking us, so no wonder its neighboring India is getting in on the act, and cyber criminals in that country accused of hitting the United States targets including the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and Heritage's Dean Cheng on how China's bad habits are spreading. Dean, take it.

DEAN CHENG, HERITAGE FOUNDATION ASIA EXPERT: Well, what we're seeing right now, is to build off your previous guests, the fact that we have a weak economy. We have a president who is unable to make commitments that he can live up to. And most recently, he almost desperately invited the Chinese premier out to Rancho Mirage, and the Chinese slapped him in the face but not even willing to spend the night at the resort. They stayed at a separate hotel, to send the message, we don't trust you, and we don't think you're going to do anything if we insult you.

MACDONALD: All right, but if you take a step back, I hear what you're saying, take a step back. Is it getting easier for any big player to get in on the act of cyber hacking or has this been a story that's always been out there that has not been reported on? Go ahead.

CHENG: It is - look. Somebody who is smart with a laptop can operate from an Internet cafe anywhere in the world, they are smart they can create botnets and they can start doing all sorts of nastiness, the problem with Mr. Snowden is, he knows all the counter measures. He knows all the things that we do to try and keep other people from being able to use that.

MACDONALD: All right, but stay on India, who is cyber hacking in India? And what are they going after?

CHENG: I think that in the case of India, you've probably got actors who are interested in commercial opportunities, contracts, who is going to make a play for an acquisition or who would - the Indians like to partner up with. Basically, you can see the people hold cards.

MACDONALD: All right, is there cyber hacking coming out of Pakistan?

CHENG: At this point there is probably cyber hacking coming out of every country, but I think that India simply for its sheer size, but also it's much more advanced IT capacity, is probably a little bit more of concern than Pakistan.

MACDONALD: Dean, are you concerned that rather than these countries building a functioning economy that they are turning instead to cyber hacking?

CHENG: I think for particularly countries whose economies are already rickety, places like Pakistan, places like Venezuela, they are going to look at this, as the way out. And it's not. I mean the thing is that at the end of the day if you really want to build an economy, you have to have a fully functional system, but for some of these countries, what they are really after is political. They want political control, and cyber is a way to do that. So, it's both econ and politics.

MACDONALD: OK. Final point. Dean, quickly, three sec - we only have a limited amount of time. Which countries are you most worried about in terms of cyber hacking the United States and their companies here?

CHENG: Well, I think China and Russia absolutely lead the pack. Believe it or not, North Korea is another source, and we are probably going to start seeing more things coming from South America.

MACDONALD: So, the final question: North Korea is cyber hacking the United States., what are they cyber hacking here?

CHENG: They are trying to break into our military, but they are also trying to break into things like our power grids and any other parts of the communications and information backbone, ways to hurt the United States, cheaply but devastatingly.

MACDONALD: OK. Dean Cheng, thank you so much for being with us tonight, it's really good to see you, sir. Next up, coming up how the government could force businesses to hire ex-cons. This sounds criminal, but it's true. Next, also thousands of pages, hundreds of surprises, and costing billions of dollars. No, I'm not talking about the health care law. You know all about that one. We're talking about the immigration bill that is giving businesses a lot of headaches.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. JEFF SESSIONS (R ) ALABAMA: On a 1200 page (INAUDIBLE), 200 pages more than the bill we were looking at last week, and no one has read. Our senators have not had a chance to read the bill.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: All right, the Senate immigration bill is starting to look a lot like the healthcare law, too long to read, too complicated to understand. And add on stocking it at the last minute like 1.5 billion bucks in stimulus for job training. To Imogen Lloyd Webber, Peter Suderman, Ron Meyer. Ron, is this health care part two, Ron?

RON MEYER, CONSESRVATIVE STRATEGIST: Oh, I think it looks like that, and for me, I think it's basically worse, because you have a bill with seemingly good intentions, and then you are just loading it up with pork, and I think that if we look at the jobs program in there, it's really not even going to help young people. And I think if a program is good, it should be brought up on its own merits. We should be talking about your unemployment and the great youth depression, but this is not the right time, immigration reform should be focused on immigration reform, and getting border security, and then figuring out how we can make sure we can take care of the folks who are here already. And that's - that has nothing to do with all we are talking about. And these pork pieces.

MACDONALD: Imogen, to Ron's point - we didn't know (inaudible) after the fact that after health care reform was said and done, here is what was in it, 300 million bucks extra Medicaid for Louisiana, more money for Massachusetts for Medicare, money for Tennessee hospitals, and look at this, Imo, $100 million to the Senator Chris Dodd Medical Center, you are concerned after the fact when all the headlines and the media goes away that these boondoggles are shoehorned in at the last minute.

IMOGEN LLOYD WEBBER, POLITICAL COMMENTATOR: From what I understand this has been happening throughout history on some level, though, to these bills. And fundamentally this may pass the Senate, surprisingly, but at great Dixie from the Dorothy of 70 (ph), that's what people are expecting. It's not going to pass the House, so, yes, we can be concerned, but believe me, the House are going to be complaining even more.

MACDONALD: So, Peter S, Imogen is not worried about the pork because it's just going to get rejected anyway. Go ahead.

PETER SUDERMAN, REASON MAGAZINE SENIOR EDITOR: I think what bills like these show us is the folly of comprehensive - comprehensive reform of any sort, whether its health care, whether it's immigration. If you are worried about immigration, if you want more immigration, if you want to find a solution to the problem of 11 million people who are here illegally, what do we do with them? Then those are the problems you should be solving, we should be creating, sane paths to immigration here in the United States rather than this incredibly screwing - incredibly complicated system that we have right now. Instead, what we're doing is, you know, focusing on trying to do everything at once, that is not immigration reform, that is - and it's bad politics.

MACDONALD: You know, so, Ron, to Peter's point, we are trying to everything - kitchen sink this thing. Trying to do everything at once. It should be just about border security and then immigration reform. Go ahead.

MEYER: Well, yeah, I think that is true. And I think that we should be looking at how to make a better legal immigration system. And I think that that deserves a debate, that deserves a focus, instead of all these other provisions, why can't we just focus - I mean it seems so simple - why can't Congress just focus on one thing at a time so the American people can comprehend what's going on?

MACDONALD: Yeah, but what would that one thing be?

MEYER: I think that they are just trying to be (inaudible)

MACDONALD: But would that one thing be, Imogen?

WEBBER: Well, I have a very different view, perhaps, I am a legal immigrant. I think absolutely you need to do something about the illegals in this country, but I think there should only be a path to residency, I don't mean there should be a path to citizenship, a man (ph) - people a year, and those who come here legally, they are the ones who deserve that path to citizenship. If you came here illegally, you should only have a path to residency.

MACDONALD: What do you mean by the difference between residency and citizenship? Go ahead.

WEBBER: So, I have a Green Card, but I am not a U.S. citizen, and I think you have to behave honorably to be a U.S. citizen, and if you dishonor the process in anyway, which you did by coming here illegally, you should never have the honor of being a U.S. citizen. You should only have to get residency, a Green Card, pay your taxes.

MACDONALD: So, that's interesting, Peter. So, have a period of time, where you are a residence and then earn your way to citizenship. What do you think?

SUDERMAN: So, this bill does not let people who are here illegally right now become citizens for more than a decade, basically they get a provisional status, and then after a decade, after a little more than a decade, they have a chance to become a citizen. So that's actually what's either something like what's in the bill right now, is a waiting period. But look, the .

(CROSSTALK)

SUDERMAN: . for coming here.

MACDONALD: Hang on. We know that. We know that that's in the bill. This is Imogen is talking about something different, though. She is saying that you have to turn in a good track record here before you become a citizen. Right, Imo?

WEBBER: Well, I'm saying that if you came here, illegally you should not be a citizen at all, which is not in the bill.

MACDONALD: So, that is the point.

WEBBER: You should only be (inaudible) residency.

MACDONALD: Peter, but that's the point. Go ahead.

SUDERMAN: You know, if that is what we're going to do, then what we need to be focusing on is creating a clearer and saner path to get here legally, and right now if you look at the process, we have done this in the recent magazine, we've laid it out. You look at the process for coming here legally for most people it is insane. It is incredibly complicated.

MACDONALD: All right. I want to bring it - I hear what you're saying. But I do want to bring it back. And let's get a fact to what we started out talking about. And Ron, you make a valid point about what happens with these bills, and that is, they become derailed, somehow, and they become a way to get votes, you have to do a buy in, right? And it becomes, of course, a big pork fest. Go ahead.

MEYER: And instead of doing what I think the other two guests are actually doing on air, which is compromising, saying, and this is something that I think would pass the House, compromise where there is no citizenship, but there is permanent legal status. I think that's amendment they could pass, something that would be a good compromise. But instead of figuring out how to compromise and how to work together, what Congress is doing is who can we pay off to gets the votes to pass this bill, and that is what the Congress has become.

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: I hear what you're saying. You're saying if you simplify it, and you just focus in, you would not have to have all this pork going on.

(CROSSTALK)

MEYER: That is what Chairman Goodlatte on the House side is exactly trying to do.

MACDONALD: Peter, what do you think of that?

SUDERMAN: I would like to see a series of bills that make it clear that the problem is that immigration is really hard, and the problem is that we have a whole bunch of people here who unauthorized, who are illegal, that need to be legalized. And that is what we need to focus on. It's good for American workers, it's good for the economy, and that's what immigration reform should be.

MACDONALD: Imogen, you get the last word. Go ahead.

WEBBER: Well, the CBO is saying the immigration bill could save American taxpayers up to a trillion dollars. So clearly the immigration reform-

MACDONALD: But they have been off with their focus (ph), though, I mean, they have been off with their numbers by a factor of 200 billion or more a year, right?

WEBBER: But can the immigration reform - needs to be sorted out. You need to sort out 11 million people here who are here illegally.

MACDONALD: OK, good points, gang, you are going to be up later in the show.

Next up, how the government is trying to make companies hire, get this, felons, ex-cons, without even knowing that they are hiring ex-cons. That is up next.

MACDONALD: Welcome back. The Obama administration is suing Dollar General and BMW over alleged unfair use of criminal background checks when they try to hire workers. Now the government claims that screenings discriminate against minorities. Now to the lawyers. We've got Nicole Deborde, who says that companies should have the right to refuse hiring ex-cons. And Jennifer Bonjean disagrees, Nicole?

NICOLE DEBORDE, ATTORNEY: Yes, I mean, a company should be able to decide who they want to hire and they should be able to decide what their criteria are, as long as they are legal. And looking for someone's criminal history is a certainly legal method of determining whether or not you want to employee that person.

MACDONALD: Jennifer, what do you think?

JENNIFER BONJEAN, ATTORNEY: Yes, of course they should have the right to look at a criminal background, just as a police officer should have the right to write a ticket to someone who is speeding, but it can also be employed in a discriminatory matter, and that is the issue. The issue is not whether employers can use criminal background checks. They can. But they cannot use it as a tool to discriminate in the same way that police officers cannot use pulling people over and giving a speeding tickets to a predominantly minority group -

MACDONALD: But, hang on, Nicole. We're talking about hiring ex-cons who could put your workers or your customers at risk. What is fallout if companies can't use this to basically screen workers? What's the fallout?

DEBORDE: Well, they can use criminal histories to decide whether or not to employ them, but the risk is if a company cannot access this information or is told they can't use the information that they've accessed in order to hire someone or not hire them, if they hire someone who is either dangerous or violent, or steals the customers' money, they could be held liable for making a choice about who to have around their customers or around their customer's money. So they could end up finding themselves on the other end of a lawsuit for hiring somebody that they did not carefully screen.

MACDONALD: Go ahead.

BONJEAN: And that is stating the obvious, really quite honestly, that is not the issue. The issue for example with BMW, for instance, is that BMW did this process they called a transitional period, and they went and they required all these individuals to reapply for their jobs, which is a dubious practice in and of itself. And after having to reapply, they found some information about certain employees, and they ended up letting about 70 African-Americans go. One woman, as an example, who had been on the job 14 years, had --

(CROSSTALK)

BONJEAN: She had a misdemeanor conviction from 20 years ago. She'd been on the job for 14 years.

MACDONALD: You are turning this into a racist issue.

BONJEAN: It is.

MACDONALD: Wait, hang on. This is not a race issue, this is about hiring workers with clean backgrounds, you are turning it into a race issue.

BONJEAN: No, it is becoming a discriminatory practice, and in fact studies have shown that white people with criminal backgrounds get call-backs at a higher percentage than African-Americans without criminal backgrounds. There are discriminatory practices in employment. We have to look at them and scrutinize them. And if this is being used as tool to discriminate, it is unlawful, and it violates the Civil Rights Act.

MACDONALD: I hear what you're saying, and, of course, that is wrong. Nicole, what I'm saying is, we're going down the road with the ESC (ph) - by the way, it's not a rule they can (inaudible), the only way they can get their point across is via lawsuits. They basically issue guidelines, and what they do is they look for high profile company names like BMW to smack them around to make their point. Aare we morphing from this being a company should be allowed to in a free market to hire who they want into a race issue? Go ahead, Nicole.

DEBORDE: It sure sounds like something that's being morphed into a race issue. I mean, the reality is that a company should be able to sue criminal backgrounds to make the choice about who they want to hire. If they want to hire someone with a criminal history background and take the chance on somebody, I am not saying that is not necessarily a bad idea, but they need to be able to make that conscious choice with the information, and that is something they should be free to do, using a criminal history background.

BONJEAN: And they are, no one is forcing companies to hire people with criminal backgrounds. That is not what is happening here.

MACDONALD: Then why are they suing?

BONJEAN: Because they are using the tool as a discriminatory practice.

MACDONALD: But why shouldn't companies be allowed to say, you know what, I don't want an ex-con or a felon in my workforce?

BONJEAN: They can say that, and if they do screening and if it's an accurate screening, they can do that.

MACDONALD: So you have no problem with that.

BONJEAN: I have no problem with it. No, what I'm saying is after the fact, that you decide you want to get rid of 70 African-American employees, and then you use some tool to do it.

MACDONALD: Nobody disagrees with you. I hear what you're saying.

BONJEAN: But that is what's happening. The ELC (ph) is not going on and doing litigation on cases that are really --

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: OK, I hear what you're saying. Go ahead, Nicole.

DEBORDE: You know, it is one of these ironic situations. The government wants to get out there and brand people as criminals by charging them with all kinds of criminal history, all kinds of things that give them criminal history, and now when a company tries to use the information that the government created in the first place by prosecuting all these people and giving them a criminal history, the government gets mad, and now sues them, and says you cannot use the criminal history that we essentially prosecuted these people for and gave them a label. So they want to give them a label, but they don't want them to use it.

MACDONALD: All right, you two have been terrific. We've got to leave it there, unfortunately. I think we could have gone another half hour on that, that was great, great stuff, you guys.

Next up, coming up, we're just a few days into summer, and as the weather is heating up, stocks are going down. New worries we're headed for a summer sell-off that will sulk you. That's up next, don't go away.

MACDONALD: Uh-oh, you know what? We had another down day on Wall Street. The Dow and the S&P both on track for their worst month in a year. No wonder, we've got scandals, we've got the Fed, we've got China, all weighing on stocks. To market insiders Ben Willis and Jonathan Murray, is it going to be a long hot summer for the market. Mr. Willis, what do you think?

BEN WILLIS, ALBERT FRIED AND CO., MANAGING DIRECTOR: It will be a long hot summer. Volatility will be key word for the summer. And we're going to continue to be moved by the central markets this central government, bankers throughout the world, have China, you can't leave out the E.U., and of course, our own fed. Tapering the market with their jawboning is what's moving the market from our perspective.

MACDONALD: Jonathan, what do you think?

JONATHAN MURRAY, UBS MANAGING DIRECTOR: I don't disagree with Ben. I think that certainly we are going to see enhanced volatility, but that doesn't mean that there are some pretty good opportunities for investors out there, Liz. I think that ironically we have to remind ourselves that the risk of buying stocks today has lessened now that markets are off about 5 percent or 6 percent.

MACDONALD: All right, Ben, you have Federal Reserve saying, stop the market, we want to get off, but does that mean investors should say, we want to get off this ride too or should they buy the downdraft, and sit tight on some of their good stocks?

WILLIS: The investors, normal tendency, the human tendency is they want to get off the roller coaster and say stop. And the fact of the matter is if you are in bond market right now, you sought that safe haven of the U.S. Treasury market in particular, you want to get off the roller coaster without a doubt. That to me interest rate risk is the biggest scare in your portfolio. On equity side, in broad market, I think that will continue to trade lower in volatility.

MACDONALD: How much lower?

WILLIS: I think another 5 percent to the down side. The China is a new one.

MACDONALD: So you're saying what's your bottom for the Dow this summer?

WILLIS: For the summer probably, into -- well below 14,000 range.

MACDONALD: And then would you start buying then?

WILLIS: I am buying some equities right now. I don't entirely disagree. Like I said -- if -- if I'm an investor that only buys the S&P 500 indices or those type of products, no, I'm not a buyer.

MACDONALD: Jonathan, what's your low on the Dow this summer? How low does it go?

MURRAY: I have no idea, Liz. I have no idea.

MACDONALD: We both need to sip cocktails in Bermuda. Seriously, just give the viewers some idea. Go ahead.

MURRAY: I do know that there are some really good companies out there that can be had at great prices and some really great companies that can be purchased at good prices. I am still a big bull on dividend paying stocks even they are sort of out of favor right now. I think if you can identify a good, solid, high quality company with a clean balance sheet that can consistently raise its dividend going forward. That is great for all of these retiring Americans.

MACDONALD: The most unreconstructed bull has to agree that the market may have gotten ahead of the recovery, but there is a big broader zoom picture going on then with the world economy, right? So you have to say, is the market really cheap right now? Should you be buying? Is it historically cheap? I see numbers saying it is cheap.

WILLIS: I love to have more of a controversy in exchange with Mr. Murray, but unfortunately I that -- that the way that individual investor should be trading. When stocks go on sale, when there is a panic throughout the world, the same way in financial crisis that we saw, you have best banks in America on sale for $1 and $2 a share. That is when real money is made.

Warren Buffet bought a chunk of Goldman Sachs and made billions of dollars because every else panicked and did not want a piece of it -- that's where you want to take a look at those stocks that have been beaten up and the dividend stocks are the ones that have taken on the chin the most --

MACDONALD: So you say buy dividend stocks?

WILLIS: That's where I would be putting my grandmother's money.

MURRAY: I am an old fashion value dividend --

MACDONALD: Blue chip dividends.

MURRAY: And to your point about valuation, Liz, I think it's interesting that if you -- look at P/Es it's not only measurement of valuation, but certainly its one measurement. Price earnings ratios, if you look at the p of the Dow Jones Industrial average seven years ago, it is rough where of it today, right? Around 14,000, 15,000 or so, same thing with the S&P 500, but the E, the denominate or is up from $88 a share in S&P 500, which is what it earned back in '07 to 110 today, so the E is up 30 percent.

MACDONALD: Corporate earnings are coming in strong. We don't have really like the accounting shenanigans from prior bubbles. Final word, Jonathan.

MURRAY: Yes. Listen, the stock market is not China. The stock market is not the fed. It's not QE. It is not tapering. The stock market is individual businesses, like fracking and horizontal drilling and 3D printing and big data and cures for cancer and other diseases. That is what you are investing in.

WILLIS: A market of stocks.

MACDONALD: There you go. Ben Willis, Jonathan Murray, so good to be with you two. Thanks so much for you time.

Guess what is back from the dead. No, not the zombies from "World War Z," Twinkies! Yes, Twinkies, coming up from the grave, don't go away.

MACDONALD: I'm happy about this news development, a Twinkie homecoming, a movie theatre in your home, and the food police hammering -- I am talking about the Twinkie story. Jonathan Hoenig, Scott Martin here for tonight`s biz blitz, so let's get to it. So first up, guess what's back? The Twinkie making its return next month after Hostess shut its doors and shut out the unions that help bring the company to bankruptcy meaning Hostess -- is the Twinkie better off without a union worker making it?

SCOTT MARTIN, ACCENT ASSET MANAGEMENT CEO: Well, clearly, E-Mac, it is because Twinkies have been losing money for years now. The last thing they need is oppressive unions to take away more of those profits. But you have to guess E-Mac this may not be that tasty of an ending for Twinkie. Because, again, when you look at Twinkie in marketplace versus more organic healthier options, I don't know anyone that bought a Twinkie or a Snowball or a Ho-ho --

JONATHAN HOENIG, CAPITALISTIC ASSET MANAGEMENT: I did, I did.

MARTIN: Without a mask on, by the way, you don't want to be seen buying those things.

MACDONALD: I don't care, I love it. I love Twinkies, and --

MARTIN: I want a picture.

MACDONALD: You know what I'm excited about Jonathan Hoenig. We have Zingers coming back, and Ho-Hos coming back, Ding Dongs. Jonathan Hoenig, should we be saying, should the company be sending a big box of Ding Dongs to that union that helped drive -- the Hostess into bankruptcy. Go ahead, Jonathan.

HOENIG: Well, they are American classics, happy they are back, Liz. Unfortunately, it was unions not the public taste that was really keeping them down. You know, in a free market there are an unlimited amount of jobs, manufacturing Twinkies, TV sets or anything that can be created. Unfortunately, it has been difficult for manufacturing companies to actually produce because the economics have to work. So it is great to see private equity investors, and job cuts, new jobs created and the Twinkies live.

MACDONALD: I like the company that bought Twinkies. They have all major food groups they have Blue Ribbon beer. They have Bumble Bee Tuna. They've got Pam cooking spray and that Golden's mustard, what are you talking about healthy choices here?

MARTIN: Exactly. Jonathan, don't make me come over there because here's the issue. I mean, if you are asking for Twinkies to carry this company into sunset, you guys are nuts. Believe me the first day, they sell them, I think it will be great, but you know, weeks, three, four, and five forget about it.

MACDONALD: All right, you made your point. Hoenig you are up first to answer this question, if Disney executives are happy with "Monster University's" Box Office finish now. What are they going to do if viewers were able to watch it at home? This is huge a trend taking a hold overseas. Disney, Sony testing a new business model that will let movie lovers rent films at home on the very same day they are released in movie theatres. Jonathan, is this a smart strategy?

HOENIG: It is terrific. Entertainment companies, Liz are innovating. Gone are days of standing in line with that big stack of grimy VHS videotapes. I mean, the whole world of entertainment from Netflix to Red Box down the line have made getting wonderful films and entertainment, better, cheaper, more accessible and more efficient for the consumers. So I think that is would be a tremendous win not only for the studios, but ultimately for the consumer who gets higher quality entertainment at a lower price.

MACDONALD: Scott, does -- are we going to see here in the United States, we're already seeing it for independent films that you get movies on pay- per-view at same time, they are in the movie theatre, is there -- do you see any time in future, Scott Martin, where the viewer at home can watch those same movies the day they are released?

MARTIN: I hope so. I think it is a big one. My VHS tapes were never grimy, thank you very much. But, I tell you --

MACDONALD: They had Twinkies all over them and Ding Dongs.

MARTIN: You are right, but, situation at movie theatre, when you go out and fill your tank up with gas, you have to park. It's very expensive so nowadays with kids and people staying home and save money, I think it is a great idea to stream the stuff right to their homes and not have to leave the house to see it.

MACDONALD: Scott Martin, I know you like healthy living so you will love this next topic. You're going to answer the first question on this one. Is Pepsi caving to food police, focusing on being not just a soda company, but also expanding to healthier options. We're going to have Pepsi selling yogurt. So Scott, are you going to be drinking a Diet Pepsi with your yogurt?

MARTIN: That's kind of a funny issue, isn't it? Now it's kind of the anti- Twinkie. I mean, they are going the other direction, which you got to get credit for. But, do you want to eat yogurt that's made by Pepsi. They have a longstanding reputation in soda, Frito-lay chips. I don't know if yogurt's going to sell real big for them.

MACDONALD: Jonathan Hoenig, is Pepsi responding to the market?

HOENIG: They are responding to the market. This is not an appeal to the health conscious people. The fact is that Greek yogurt is like what hot wings was in 2010. It's like what the avocado was in 2006, a hot food trend. So I think Pepsi is just really capitalizing on this. They are out to make money. I don't think that America's waistline is their number one priority nor should it be.

MACDONALD: Pepsi is not responding to the food police, do you think they are?

MARTIN: No, but, you have to fit the company or say the product into the image. Listen, I'm all for them expanding their product line. Yes, the Greek yogurt area is growing considerably, but still, if you're at the store, you think of Pepsi, you are buying soda.

MACDONALD: You know, I for one, dipping my Frito-Lay chips into my yogurt with my Diet Pepsi.

MARTIN: It sounds tasty to me.

MACDONALD: I'll be having my Ding Dongs smeared over with Golden Mustard how is that?

MARTIN: You go on those diets, and we'll come back in a year.

MACDONALD: We'll say woo-hoo with a Pepsi blue ribbon beer. Good to be with you, gang, so funny and so smart.

Next up, this 4th of July, get ready for some fireworks, but not in the sky, at the super market because you know, what, your barbecue will burn a hole your wallet.

MACDONALD: Well, the 4th of July is almost here, before you start grilling, prepared to get grilled at the supermarket because food prices are exploding like fireworks, ground beef, chicken breast, potatoes, all up significantly from last year. So you know what is up? Let's ask commodity analyst, Phil Flynn. Phil, what is going to with these food prices going up?

PHIL FLYNN, THE PRICE FUTURES GROUP: You know, I tell you, it has a lot to do with a lot of issues. I think more than anything it was last year's drought. You know cost of feed for chickens and cattle went through the roof, that is one of the reasons why the price of steak is approaching $5 a pound toward the 4th of July. That is almost un-American, you know, how could you not have a thing without steak? Then chicken going up. Only thing that is flat right now are hotdogs and I guess, hotdogs is pretty American, but you're going to have to stick to that.

MACDONALD: Let's break it down. Are you having a cheap bas barbecue with cheap food?

FLYNN: Right, you can bring back Twinkies. But, you know, the bottom line is that we had a challenging year, when it comes to cattle, next year, I think they will look better, global demand will be down, it looks like we'll have a pretty get crop. The prices should be down, one thing that government continues to want us to pay higher prices they find new ways to do it, instead of taking corn, feeding it to cattle and chicken so my chicken wings are cheaper they put it in our gas tank.

They will improve that that has been another thing, a lot of chicken producers are screaming bloody murder, saying you are driving up the cost of feed. It is harder for me to feed my chickens. So, you know, at the end of the day, it's going to cost us all more.

MACDONALD: Phil, you make such an important point because we had big agricultural company executives taking at Capitol Hill and saying, you know what? This is just foolish what you are doing with ethanol and corn in the gas tank. It is not working it is making corn more expensive, and making gas prices more expensive and ruining the gas tank.

FLYNN: It is, now with this rule by the Supreme Court, the 15 percent, you know, it could do damage to your vehicle. A lot of the carmakers are not going to say that warranty is valid because they didn't produce these vehicles and these engines for 15 percent ethanol. It will be a scary time, but government does not want to hear that. They think this is a good deal. It's good for the environment. Tell that to people around the world who are starving right now. It's not such a great idea.

MACDONALD: You know that is a concern, you know that poor people around the world, they are not getting the food supply as they could. But that point about car warranty may not cover your gas tank if basically corn ethanol wrecks it. Is that true?

FLYNN: It's true, a lot is not just automobile makers, but small engine makers, you know, lawn mowers, your snow blowers. You know, a lot of these makers are saying we didn't sign for this. We produced an engine that was supposed to be protecting 10 percent ethanol. Nobody said 15 percent and they think it could damage some of the vehicles. The people on other side say, it is not going to impact anything, but tell that, if you have a problem, your gas tank rusts out and you want to get it fixed they will tell you sorry, Charlie, you are out of luck.

MACDONALD: Why chicken? Why is it going up so much?

FLYNN: It was really the drought last year. Remember last Super Bowl, I was panicked they were talking about a chicken wing shortage that was you know, a throw away item here. And then, then we have shortage. We have a big price spike on chicken wings then the prices came back down. A lot of it has been the drought. Feed cost has gone through the roof, you look at price of corn, it has been through the roof. I do think it is going to ease a little bit, but, you know not fast enough for the 4th of July.

MACDONALD: You say food prices are going to come down, is that your final word?

FLYNN: They will come down. We have a good crop this year. China is slowing down a little bit. Pricing should come down once government figures out a new way to waste food.

MACDONALD: OK, Phil Flynn, thank you so much. Always good to be with you, sir. Thanks so much for your time.

Next up, tech companies fighting back against government snooping, but you will not believe the next story, could it be just for show, they gave a big fat award to NSA top guy. We are going to let you in on the next big secret, don't go away.

MACDONALD: All right, on the surface tech companies appear to be fighting back against NSA snooping, but you dig deeper, you might come up with a different opinion because a trade group representing Microsoft and Google and the like just gave NSA Head General Keith Alexander the, quote, "Government Executive Of The Year Award" for this year. A weird way to express disappointment and we're back with Peter and Ron and Imogen.

IMOGEN LLOYD WEBBER, POLITICAL COMMENTATOR: Silicon Valley are in bed with the government, the former head of Facebook security now works for NSA and you look at these lobbying numbers, Facebook money on lobbies up 196 percent last year. They want the government on the side.

MACDONALD: Here is the thing, Ron Meyer, Google and Facebook and Microsoft, saying that is terrible, we're getting pressure by U.S. to give information over, but here you have one of the biggest tech lobby groups giving an award to the NSA. Is the tech crowd, is Silicon Valley becoming more like Wall Street with the turn style between Silicon Valley and Washington, D.C.?

MEYER: Well, it makes business sense for them to do it unfortunately and that is the problem.

MACDONALD: Why all of the shock, shock? You know from "Casablanca" on part of the tech crowd when they are doing this on the side.

MEYER: You talk about two different parts of the company, one is the PR side talking with customers. The other is lobbying side talking with government. The problem is they don't want people to think that is what they are doing, but they are, from a consumer perspective this worries me, young people are furious over this that we have some companies we trust with most private information working with the government and allowing them to do the large general warrants.

MACDONALD: Peter, does this undercut tech crowd's credibility?

SUDERMAN: I think those big tech companies like Google and Facebook are really in a tough position because they have to ask themselves, is it more trouble to work with the federal government or is it more --

MACDONALD: That's not my question. Is this undercut their credibility when tech lobby is giving an award to head of NSA, and we have a turn style between Silicon Valley and Washington D.C., with law enforcement and surveillance crowd?

SUDERMAN: You know, certainly is does not make it easier for them, but that is my point.

MACDONALD: Does it under cut their credibility?

SUDERMAN: It does not make it easier for them to oppose the government efforts. So in some ways it had the potential to do, but this is what I'm trying to say they have a tough choice to make. So when federal government comes knocking on their door, they have to decide do we answer or not.

MACDONALD: Does it under cut their credibility when they get so upset?

WEBBER: Of course it does, on many levels we should have expected it. We knew, but problem is money and politics. American politicians spend over $7 billion last year, getting re-elected. They have to raise that money, and get it from somewhere. They get it from big business.

MACDONALD: You know, Ron, the question, I'm thinking, could the tech crowd have avoided this. Could they have -- tech crowd have gone around this, said, we're going to like we sell our information to advertisers, tech crowd makes money marketing from giving in account to marketers -- giving information to marketers, could they say we'll sell the information to the government.

MEYER: Well, I think that would be a more open process, I think it -- might make people read the terms of agreement when you join these sites, if you know your information is going to the government. I feel that users don't know that, it would be a more open process.

MACDONALD: Peter, tech crowd is feeling put in a corner. Go ahead.

SUDERMAN: I mean, with question of whether or not they could have sold it, you have to ask, whether the federal government would have been willing to pay for it the issue that tech community has learned that it is difficult to ignore requests of the federal government, if you call them requests.

MEYER: Quote, unquote.

SUDERMAN: They are demands, Microsoft tried in 90s and found out activity easier to play ball.

MACDONALD: But why could they have said you can -- you know stomp your feet all you like we'll sell it to you.

MEYER: Tell that to a court order.

SUDERMAN: Whether federal government would have paid.

MACDONALD: I hear what you are saying, Ron, about the FISA court, but, you know I understand the weight and authority of the FISA court, I get it but you know, these are not you know, the lilies of the valley, they are big companies. And they are going to buckle under a FISA court order. I understand they have to comply, but do you feel they could have put up more of a fight.

MEYER: I think it is a double standard, you add Google opposing internet regulation bill last year, they are companies of people, when it looks good for them, and good to be in with government they are, they are losing a ton of credibility.

MACDONALD: Imogen, go ahead.

WEBBER: They want government on their side for tax, and antitrust legislation, and legislation to privacy, of course, they are not going to turn to government say go away.

MACDONALD: You say, they can't, they would poison the well of goodwill.

WEBBER: I'm saying they need government on their side.

MACDONALD: All right, Peter, final word.

SUDERMAN: I guess, I feel like you know, too much to -- it may be too much to expect Facebook and Google to really put up a huge amount of resistance given their relationship with federal government, and what federal government can do to them.

MACDONALD: Thank you for watching America. I hope you have a good evening.

SOCIAL MEDIA PLATFORMS MUST SAFEGUARD THEIR USERS FROM EXPOSURE TO SHOCKING VIDEOS, WRITES SARAH BLAKE

For two long hours on Easter Sunday, anyone who wanted could watch again and again as the light died in Cleveland grandfather Robert Godwin's eyes.

Shot in the head after being randomly chosen for a murder-on-camera by self-described "monster" Steve Stephens, Godwin's death was shared by more than a thousand people on Facebook before the social media platform yanked the video.

Last month, dozens of voyeurs watched from their screens in real-time as a 15-year-old Chicago girl was gang-raped. In the same city, two men and two women, all 18, were charged in January after live-streaming themselves torturing a special needs student.

About the same time, footage of a 12-year-old girl hanging herself stayed on Facebook for two weeks, and Islamic extremists from the Middle East to Europe regularly share videos of mass murder and grisly executions by their child soldiers.

All of it is there to see and easy to find on the world's biggest social media platform, which is at the centre of a growing storm of criticism for not doing enough to police the community it has created.

"We have a lot more to do here. We're reminded of this this week by the tragedy in Cleveland. Our hearts go out to the family and friends of Robert Godwin Sr, and we have a lot of work," Facebook CEO and founder Mark Zuckerberg says.

"We will keep doing all of what we can to keep tragedies like this from happening." Zuckerberg was speaking at his company's annual developer conference last Tuesday and turned then to business. But many are questioning whether Facebook is actually doing "all of what we can".

"There are really horrific and heinous acts happening online, from child pornography to extremism, to trolling, to cybercrime and malware viruses," says Professor Hany Farid from Dartmouth College in New Hampshire. "You name it, the internet is becoming a kind of a cesspool, and I think the social media companies have been very slow to respond, frustratingly slow." Big tech companies including Facebook, Google, YouTube and Twitter argue they are dealing with so much data it's impossible to monitor every video and photo their users post. But the booming success of the social media behemoths shows they are in control of their content when it makes commercial sense.

"There's really not been that much action trying to address this in a serious way, and what frustrates me is that the companies will say, 'Well it's a really hard problem. We have a massive amount of data, we have a massive amount of users and we can't possibly regulate'," Farid says.

"I find that sort of inexcusable. The 'massive amount of data, the massive amount of users' doesn't seem to prevent them from being very effective in advertising, in collecting personal data and selling that personal data - making really a lot of money leveraging that data.

"They harvest the data and they make a lot of money doing it, so you can't just say this is really complicated - because obviously you have figured out in certain dimensions how to manage the data." Most social media companies rely on their users to report offensive content for their moderators to evaluate and then take steps including removal and reporting it to law enforcement agencies.

"This is like the police saying, 'We've got a bunch of laws on the books and we are going to sit in our office all day long and we are going to wait for people to tell us what they think is wrong'. That's their model and that's completely insane," Farid says.

Most of this monitoring is then outsourced - such as the investigations Google introduced in the wake of the "fake news" controversy during the 2016 election, which are being helmed by Politifact and Snopes.

There is also an army of Facebook and Twitter minimum-wage human moderators working out of offices in Asian countries, including the Philippines, who Farid describes as "traumatised, looking at this horrific content all day long".

"So even at that level, it barely rates on Facebook's radar," he says. "On the other hand, how many people do they have on the advertising side, how many people do they have on the analytics side, how many engineers developing the next generation of Facebook features? The labour distribution is a good indication of how seriously they take it." Cyber safety expert Hemanshu Nigam agrees social media companies have been too slow to respond to the proliferation of vile content, a problem compounded by their pace of growth.

"Part of the problem is that with Facebook, what we are experiencing is a technology company that is slowly evolving into a media company, and also evolving into a political powerhouse.

"In many ways that's creating an identity crisis, because each one of these identities comes with different responsibilities," he says.

Nigam runs online safety consultancy SSP Blue, but was formerly chief security officer of MySpace, where every piece of media was moderated before being posted.

"There was a human being looking at it and if it was deemed inappropriate, then it was fingerprinted so it could not be shared by another user on the site," he says.

"Those were very proactive measures we took." Nigam says such a model wouldn't now work due to the sheer number of users of Facebook, Google and Twitter, but a combination of human and computer-driven moderation is possible.

"One of the greatest challenges that Facebook faced (this week) was that the content kept being shared, and the question that was left unanswered is why that video wasn't stopped," Nigam says.

"When you're the platform, you're the mayor, the regulator, the legislator, the enforcer, the first responder, the educator. You have to serve every role in that society that typically a government serves."

Farid says less eyes on each video would take away one of the key motivations for sick people to share their most depraved acts.For Mr Godwin's family, the sharing of his death only added to their pain. "Please please please stop retweeting that video and report anyone who has posted it! That is my grandfather show some respect #Cleveland," his grandson Ryan Godwin tweeted. Tellingly, his message has been retweeted more than 30,000 times - far more than the number of views for the vile snuff film that stole his family patriarch.

urn:contentItem:5P3B-MWK1-JCPJ-W1R5-00000-00Soaring expectations pose test for Amazon, Alphabet and Facebook2017-07-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:44ZLexisNexisSoaring expectations pose test for Amazon, Alphabet and FacebookBy Tim Bradshaw and Leslie Hook in San Francisco

Editor's note : This story is available as a result of a content partnership with The Financial Times. Subscribers will see stories like this every day on our website (and in our daily emails) as an added value to your subscription.

The world's three most valuable internet companies - Alphabet, Amazon and Facebook- report earnings this week after a rally in tech stocks that has sent investor expectations to all-time highs.

The trio's outsized valuations raise the stakes for second-quarter results and analysts are warning that any signs of a break in their growth momentum could send shares tumbling.

The collective value of the S&P 500 technology sector surpassed its dotcom bubble peak of March 2000 for the first time last week. Investors have rewarded companies that have come to dominate their sector, as Googleand Facebookhave in online advertising and Amazon does in ecommerce, while punishing smaller rivals such as Snap that struggle to match their scale.

"Any signs of a break in the momentum of the business obviously would change the trajectory of the shares," says Jan Dawson, analyst at Jackdaw Research. "It is hard to see how these companies' valuations could go any further than they are at the moment, unless there's some big upside surprise. There's a lot more potential for a short-term correction than a steepening of the trajectory."

Amazon and Alphabet typically see their individual stock prices jump by at least 5 per cent the day after posting their latest financial results, according to data from Bloomberg. Six months ago was a notable exception, when all three saw their shares drop in the wake of their fourth-quarter earnings reports.

"People can be easily spooked by these stocks" in such situations, says Mr Dawson, given that their results are normally so predictable.

The pull back earlier this year was shortlived: Facebookshares have gained almost 30 per cent in the past six months, while Alphabet is up 20 per cent and Amazon 27 per cent over the same period.

Facebook's longer-term rally has been all the more remarkable given that its shares have fallen the day after it reported earnings for each of the past three quarters, despite consistently beating Wall Street's forecasts on both revenues and earnings.

Facebookhas warned for some time that its rate of growth would slow as it reached saturation point in the number of advertisements it could show in its main app's news feed. However, the forecast slowdown has so far failed to materialise. Meanwhile, it has been inserting more ads in new places across its "family" of apps, including Instagram and Messenger.

Like Facebook, Alphabet has benefited in recent years from huge growth in mobile advertising. Google's vast scale across both search and display advertising on the web has made it so difficult for others to compete that its rivals are ganging up against it, as the likes of News Corp and other US newspaper owners are doing with the News Media Alliance, to demand regulatory change.

While concerns over ad placement on YouTube and other Googleproperties may nibble away at its performance on the edges, the area that is more likely to cause a surprise are Alphabet's "Other Bets" - divisions that include self-driving cars and healthcare technology - where investment often outstrips income.

Cost-conscious investors will also be scouring Amazon's results for signs that it is readying itself for another period of investment.

Despite strong growth in Amazon Web Services, the cloud computing division that accounts for the lion's share of the group's profits, Amazon remains one of the least profitable among the big tech companies, with a net income margin of just 1.8 per cent over the past four quarters.

urn:contentItem:4R2N-BDH0-TW8C-J0KB-00000-00So-Called Patent Reform Act Will Enable Big-Tech Goliaths to Operate Beyond the Law Cautions TPL Group's Dan Leckrone2007-11-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:44ZLexisNexisBusiness EditorsTechnology WritersLegal WritersSo-Called Patent Reform Act Will Enable Big-Tech Goliaths to Operate Beyond the Law Cautions TPL Group's Dan LeckroneCUPERTINO, Calif.

In the following opinion piece, "Beware Patent Reform," which published today in the San Francisco Chronicle, Dan Leckrone, Chairman of The TPL Group, asserts that Big-Tech Goliaths are wielding their monopolistic powers to smother innovation in America. "The Goliaths are pushing for a major change to our venerable Patent System so that they can misappropriate intellectual property without risk and roll over competitors who can't afford to defend their rights," he warned.

According to Leckrone, the Patent Reform Act (S. 1145) now before the Senate, if enacted, will be the coup de grace for the US Patent System as well as for the inventors, small businesses, universities and innovation it has historically protected. He contends that by financing and forcing this misguided special-interest legislation, the Big-Tech Goliaths will no longer need to operate beyond the law as they do now - but they can operate within it, free to take what they choose without fear of having to pay for it.

In his opinion piece, Leckrone confirmed that the self-styled "Coalition for Patent Fairness" (CPF) continues to be well funded by Big-Tech Goliaths seeking to force passage of the so-called Patent "Reform" Act. He noted that public financial information for the seven CPF founders, namely, Apple, Cisco, Dell, HP, Intel, Micron and Oracle, reveal that these Goliaths are not burdened with patent litigation costs/awards as the CPF claims. In fact, the seven Goliaths paid out a trifling 1/9th of 1 percent (0.11%) of their revenues in patent awards during the 11 years between 1996 and 2006 -- far less than the relevant R&D would have cost them.

Economist Pat Choate Proves CPF Claims False

According to a recent policy paper authored by economist Pat Choate, the CPF falsely claims that patent lawsuits are hampering the ability of its Goliath founders to finance R&D when in fact, disclosed patent settlements of the CPF founders equaled 1.5 percent of their total R&D investment, confirming that patent litigation has had no significant impact on the CPF research and development activities. Moreover, the CPF founders regularly go to the "rocket dockets" where they are prolific plaintiffs. Choate's policy paper noted that in the 11-year period of 1996-2006, the seven CPF founders disclosed a total of $1.9 billion in patent settlement payments, an average of $173 million per year. During that same time, these seven corporations had collective revenues of more than $1.7 trillion. Choate's complete policy paper can be accessed athttp://www.tplgroup.net/legislation/pdf/Analysis103007.pdf.

According to Leckrone, the real motivation for the CPF attack on the Patent System and law is probably best demonstrated by the policy paper's report that CPF founders have been involved in over 350 antitrust and price fixing lawsuits over the 11-year period, displaying their arrogant disregard for the laws we all have to live by.

"Choate's paper also reports that the ratio of lawsuits to patents issued has remained less than 1.5 percent for many years debunking also the CPF claim that there is some sort of patent litigation crisis, and making it clear that the case being made for the Patent Reform Act now before the Senate is baseless," said Leckrone. "It is ironic that these Goliaths now seek to weaken the very patent system that enabled them to achieve their growth and stature by protecting their intellectual property from infringement."

Leckrone believes that innovation from smaller companies represents real competition to the Goliaths, and the US Patent System has been and continues to be effective in leveling the playing field. "Our legendary patent system has been instrumental in making America the cradle of innovation. Indeed, it has spawned the world's most effective start-up culture with Silicon Valley as its poster child. It has also fueled the development of the world's most effective venture-capital infrastructure, which in turn has driven economic and job growth."

Key to Improving Patent Quality

"Our Patent System has been a treasure to our country and it deserves better than a rushed passage of seriously flawed legislation," asserted Leckrone. "Lost in the pressure for change is the recognition that the key to improvement will come from our support of the talented men and women who work in the patent office. It is they who are charged with examining and issuing quality patents worthy of their constitutional basis. We need to help the patent office continuously improve the quality of the examination so that only worthy patents are issued."

Growing Opposition to the Patent Reform Act of 2007

Opposition to the so-called Patent Reform Act continues to grow across America with inventors, venture capitalists, universities, trade associations, labor organizations and more than 400 business corporations small and large voicing their concerns. The TPL Group, which has made it a high priority to spread the word about the flawed legislation before Congress, is urging all Americans to write to their Senators. To help others communicate their concern, the company has posted abundant resources on its website at www.tplgroup.net/legislationincluding contact information for elected representatives.

About The TPL Group

Founded in 1988, Technology Properties Limited (The TPL Group) has emerged as a global coalition of high technology enterprises involved in the development, management and commercialization of Intellectual Property (IP) assets as well as the design, manufacture and sales of proprietary products based on these same IP assets. Among the advanced products that The TPL Group enterprises continue to develop and bring to market are multicore microprocessors as well as other system-on-chip solutions for distributed digital media processing applications. For more information, visitwww.tplgroup.net.

San Francisco Chronicle Op Ed Follows

Beware patent reform

Dan Leckrone

Monday, November 5, 2007

High-tech Goliaths who routinely flaunt the law by abusing their market power are consistently rebuked for regarding themselves as being "above the law" -- and justifiably so. The Patent Reform Act now up for vote in the U.S. Senate is but the latest blatant example of how Goliaths are wielding their power to smother innovation. Indeed, the Goliaths seek a major overhaul of our patent system that would pave the way for them to roll over competitors by misappropriating their intellectual property.

The Goliaths are using their economic power to induce persons and organizations with political clout to force changes to the laws of the land so that Goliaths no longer need to operate "beyond the law" -- but within it, out of reach and free from sanction.

Thoughtful examination reveals that this proposed legislation would change the calculations of damages imposed on patent infringers in a way that would drastically limit the amounts they must pay patent owners; create a new post-grant, quasi-judicial review process that would provide infringers new opportunities to challenge patents that have already been issued; and change the rules on venue -- where a patent holder can sue an infringer -- in a way that would favor infringers over patent owners.

More evidence of the monopolistic power wielded by the Goliaths was unmasked and checked recently, thanks to the European Union's top anti-trust regulator. In a series of recent charges leveled by the EU anti-trust body, first against Intel in July 2007 and then against Microsoft two months later, both global giants were cited for monopolistic practices aimed at stifling competition. The cited abuses were not new as both Intel and Microsoft were sanctioned earlier for similar practices by the governments of Korea and Japan, and have faced, and continue to face U.S. government scrutiny and sanctions.

Now, these high-tech Goliaths have slipped the Patent Reform Act of 2007 through committees in both the House and the Senate. This bill, if enacted, will be the coup de grace for the U.S. Patent System as well as for the inventors and innovation it protects. The self-styled Coalition for Patent Fairness (www.patentfairness.org) continues to be well funded by high-tech Goliaths seeking to force passage of this act. Financial information for Apple, Cisco, Dell, HP, Intel, Micron and Oracle, reveal that these Goliaths are not as burdened with patent litigation costs/awards as the coalition claims. In fact, the seven Goliaths paid out 1/9th of 1 percent (0.11 percent) of their revenues in patent awards during the 11 years between 1996 and 2006, according to Pat Choate, an economist and author on manufacturing policy.

In a recent policy paper, Choate reported that the coalition founders collectively invested more than $131 billion on R&D for at period. He noted that disclosed patent settlements equaled 1.5 percent of their total R&D investment, which suggests that patent litigation has had no significant impact on their research and development activities. When one considers the fact that the ratio of lawsuits to patents issued has remained less than 1.5 percent for many years, it is clear that the case being made for the Patent Reform Act now before the Senate is false. In the 11-year period of 1996-2006, the seven coalition founders disclosed a total of $1.9 billion in patent settlement payments, an average of $173 million per year. During that same time, these seven corporations had collective revenues of more than $1.7 trillion.

It is ironic that these companies now seek to weaken the very patent system that enabled them to achieve their growth and stature by protecting their intellectual property from infringement. Clearly, innovation from smaller companies represents real competition to the Goliaths, and our patent system has proved effective in leveling the playing field. Our legendary patent system has been instrumental in making America the cradle of innovation. Indeed, it has spawned the world's most effective start-up culture with Silicon Valley as its poster child. It has also fueled the development of the world's most effective venture-capital infrastructure, which in turn has driven economic and job growth.

Protecting U.S. innovation directly translates to preventing the exportation of U.S. jobs. The American patent system does not need the major changes that the Goliaths are seeking to impose. Rather than this so called reform, we need to help the U.S. Patent Office continuously improve the quality of the examination so that only worthy patents are issued. Any legislation regarding our patent system should rehabilitate, not debilitate.

Dan Leckroneis chairman of the TPL Group in Cupertino. The TPL Group develops and commercializes intellectual property assets. E-mail him at chairman@tplgroup.net. For more information, go towww.tplgroup.net/legislation.

Oct 10, 2019( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Reuters Sophie Huynh, a cross asset strategist at Societe Generale, says the US has less than a year to go before a recession hits and a bear market in US stocks sets in. Still, Huynh says investors should understand there are limits to how bad things are going to get for US stocks in particular. She's recommending three trades ahead of that downturn. Two of them are built around the market's big winners continuing to outperform.

But for a third, she's saying it's time to pull the ripcord. Click here for more BI Prime stories[1]. The three-legged stool is a classic approach to retirement. And Sophie Huynh, a cross asset strategist at Societe Generale, says a different three-legged stool can help investors prepare for a rough stretch in the stock market. Huynh expects the US economy to go into a recession in the second quarter of 2020, leading to a downturn for stocks. But her prediction also calls for a relatively mild recession. And just as important, she said there are powerful trends that limit how badly US stocks are going to get hurt. Even if the Federal Reserve can't prevent a recession, its interest rate cuts[2] will be a key source of support for the market, Huynh says. She thinks the high dividends of US companies will help as well. And while a recession always hurts corporate earnings growth — which has historically been the biggest driver of stock prices — Huynh says this would be a mild recession after a period of already-slow growth. That means earnings forecasts won't fall as much as they usually do when a recession hits, and that means stocks won't be punished as badly. With that in mind, she's offering three trades to help investors thrive during the downturn.(1) US stocks, especially dividend aristocratsYes, Huynh says US stocks still make more sense than equities in other areas even with a recession looming. Falling interest rates are a huge advantage, she writes, as US equities tend to beat all of their international competitors when rates start to go down. She backs that up with this chart that shows US stock breaking away from their peers and staying on top for more than a year after the rate-cutting cycle begins. If that weren't enough, she adds that US stocks now offer much better yields than Treasury bonds, which has the important effect of limiting the downside for those stocks by supporting their valuations. One way for investors to add exposure to those dividend growth companies is the ProShares S...00 Dividend Aristocrats ETF[3].(2) Buy emerging markets, sell big techHuynh is telling investors to short the Nasdaq 100[4] in favor of emerging markets stocks, as three major developments make big tech look less appealing than it has for most of the past decade. She points to growing regulatory scrutiny of tech companies[5], new tax rules[6] that could hamper their profitability, and pressure on their earnings growth as reasons for caution around technology companies. "Earnings growth, economic growth resilience and the search for yield are key for this investment idea," she wrote. Investors can get exposure to emerging markets stocks through the iShares MSCI Emerging Markets ETF[7]. Read more: As nervous investors flood into trades designed to minimize volatility, Goldman says they're confusing steady prices with real stability — and could be courting disaster[8](3) Stick with the S...00While Huynh has a positive view of US stocks in general, she said investors are drawing distinctions between different groups of stocks and recommends going long on the S...00 as compared to the small cap Russell 2000. That's because investors are getting nervous about betting on companies with riskier debt, and there are far more of those on the Russell 2000 than on the S...00. "Doubts about the effect of central bank easing on the real economy and/or fears of illiquidity have triggered more differentiation within risky assets," Huynh said.
